member.name: T:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.CurveLoopType
member.summary: Defines how the value is determined for position before first point or after the end point on the .

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.CurveLoopType.Constant
member.summary: The value of will be evaluated as first point for positions before the beginning and end point for positions after the end.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.CurveLoopType.Cycle
member.summary: The positions will wrap around from the end to beginning of the for determined the value.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.CurveLoopType.CycleOffset
member.summary: The positions will wrap around from the end to beginning of the . The value will be offset by the difference between the values of first and end multiplied by the wrap amount. If the position is before the beginning of the the difference will be subtracted from its value; otherwise the difference will be added.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.CurveLoopType.Oscillate
member.summary: The value at the end of the act as an offset from the same side of the toward the opposite side.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.CurveLoopType.Linear
member.summary: The linear interpolation will be performed for determined the value.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.CurveTangent
member.summary: Defines the different tangent types to be calculated for points in a .

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.CurveTangent.Flat
member.summary: The tangent which always has a value equal to zero.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.CurveTangent.Linear
member.summary: The tangent which contains a difference between current tangent value and the tangent value from the previous .

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.CurveTangent.Smooth
member.summary: The smoouth tangent which contains the inflection between and by taking into account the values of both neighbors of the .

member.summary: The SortingFilteringCollection class provides efficient, reusable sorting and filtering based on a configurable sort comparer, filter predicate, and associate change events.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.GamePlatform.RaiseAsyncRunLoopEnded
member.summary: Raises the AsyncRunLoopEnded event. This method must be called by derived classes when the asynchronous run loop they start has stopped running.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.GamePlatform.BeforeInitialize
member.summary: Gives derived classes an opportunity to do work before any components are initialized. Note that the base implementation sets IsActive to true, so derived classes should either call the base implementation or set IsActive to true by their own means.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.GamePlatform.BeforeRun
member.summary: Gives derived classes an opportunity to do work just before the run loop is begun. Implementations may also return false to prevent the run loop from starting.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.GamePlatform.Exit
member.summary: When implemented in a derived, ends the active run loop.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.GamePlatform.BeforeDraw(Microsoft.Xna.Framework.GameTime)

member.name: M:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.GamePlatform.ResetElapsedTime
member.summary: MSDN: Use this method if your game is recovering from a slow-running state, and ElapsedGameTime is too large to be useful. Frame timing is generally handled by the Game class, but some platforms still handle it elsewhere. Once all platforms rely on the Game class's functionality, this method and any overrides should be removed.

member.name: E:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.GameWindow.TextInput
member.summary: Use this event to retrieve text for objects like textbox's. This event is not raised by noncharacter keys. This event also supports key repeat. For more information this event is based off: http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-AU/library/system.windows.forms.control.keypress.aspx
member.remarks: This event is only supported on the Windows DirectX, Windows OpenGL and Linux platforms.

member.param: The coordinate on one axis of vertex 1 of the defining triangle.
The coordinate on the same axis of vertex 2 of the defining triangle.
The coordinate on the same axis of vertex 3 of the defining triangle.
The normalized barycentric (areal) coordinate b2, equal to the weighting factor for vertex 2, the coordinate of which is specified in value2.
The normalized barycentric (areal) coordinate b3, equal to the weighting factor for vertex 3, the coordinate of which is specified in value3.
member.returns: Cartesian coordinate of the specified point with respect to the axis being used.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.MathHelper.Lerp(System.Single,System.Single,System.Single)
member.summary: Linearly interpolates between two values.
member.param: Value between 0 and 1 indicating the weight of value2.
member.returns: Interpolated value.
member.remarks: This method performs the linear interpolation based on the following formula: value1 + (value2 - value1) * amount. Passing amount a value of 0 will cause value1 to be returned, a value of 1 will cause value2 to be returned. See for a less efficient version with more precision around edge cases.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.MathHelper.LerpPrecise(System.Single,System.Single,System.Single)
member.summary: Linearly interpolates between two values. This method is a less efficient, more precise version of . See remarks for more info.
member.param: Value between 0 and 1 indicating the weight of value2.
member.returns: Interpolated value.
member.remarks: This method performs the linear interpolation based on the following formula: ((1 - amount) * value1) + (value2 * amount). Passing amount a value of 0 will cause value1 to be returned, a value of 1 will cause value2 to be returned. This method does not have the floating point precision issue that has. i.e. If there is a big gap between value1 and value2 in magnitude (e.g. value1=10000000000000000, value2=1), right at the edge of the interpolation range (amount=1), will return 0 (whereas it should return 1). This also holds for value1=10^17, value2=10; value1=10^18,value2=10^2... so on. For an in depth explanation of the issue, see below references: Relevant Wikipedia Article: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linear_interpolation#Programming_language_support Relevant StackOverflow Answer: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/4353525/floating-point-linear-interpolation#answer-23716956

member.name: T:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Audio.AudioEmitter
member.summary: Represents a 3D audio emitter. Used to simulate 3D audio effects.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Audio.AudioEmitter.#ctor
member.summary: Initializes a new AudioEmitter instance.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Audio.AudioEmitter.DopplerScale
member.summary: Gets or sets a scale applied to the Doppler effect between the AudioEmitter and an AudioListener.

remarks.para: Defaults to 1.0
A value of 1.0 leaves the Doppler effect unmodified.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Audio.AudioEmitter.Forward
member.summary: Gets or sets the emitter's forward vector.

remarks.para: Defaults to Vector3.Forward. (new Vector3(0, 0, -1))
Used with AudioListener.Velocity to calculate Doppler values.
The Forward and Up values must be orthonormal.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Audio.AudioEmitter.Position
member.summary: Gets or sets the position of this emitter.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Audio.AudioEmitter.Up
member.summary: Gets or sets the emitter's Up vector.

remarks.para: Defaults to Vector3.Up. (new Vector3(0, -1, 1)).
The Up and Forward vectors must be orthonormal.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Audio.AudioEmitter.Velocity
member.summary: Gets or sets the emitter's velocity vector.

remarks.para: Defaults to Vector3.Zero.
This value is only used when calculating Doppler values.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Audio.AudioListener
member.summary: Represents a 3D audio listener. Used when simulating 3D Audio.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Audio.AudioListener.Forward
member.summary: Gets or sets the listener's forward vector.

remarks.para: Defaults to Vector3.Forward. (new Vector3(0, 0, -1))
Used with AudioListener.Velocity and AudioEmitter.Velocity to calculate Doppler values.
The Forward and Up vectors must be orthonormal.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Audio.AudioListener.Position
member.summary: Gets or sets the listener's position.
member.remarks: Defaults to Vector3.Zero.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Audio.AudioListener.Up
member.summary: Gets or sets the listener's up vector..

remarks.para: Defaults to Vector3.Up (New Vector3(0, -1, 0)).
Used with AudioListener.Velocity and AudioEmitter.Velocity to calculate Doppler values.
The values of the Forward and Up vectors must be orthonormal.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Audio.AudioListener.Velocity
member.summary: Gets or sets the listener's velocity vector.

remarks.para: Defaults to Vector3.Zero.
Scaled by DopplerScale to calculate the Doppler effect value applied to a Cue.
This value is only used to calculate Doppler values.

member.summary: Stops playing a SoundEffectInstance, either immediately or as authored.
member.param: Determined whether the sound stops immediately, or after playing its release phase and/or transitions.
member.remarks: Stopping a sound with the immediate argument set to false will allow it to play any release phases, such as fade, before coming to a stop.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Audio.SoundEffectInstance.Dispose
member.summary: Releases the resources held by this .

member.name: M:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Audio.SoundEffectInstance.Dispose(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Releases the resources held by this .
member.param: If set to true, Dispose was called explicitly.
member.remarks: If the disposing parameter is true, the Dispose method was called explicitly. This means that managed objects referenced by this instance should be disposed or released as required. If the disposing parameter is false, Dispose was called by the finalizer and no managed objects should be touched because we do not know if they are still valid or not at that time. Unmanaged resources should always be released.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Audio.SoundEffectInstance.IsLooped
member.summary: Enables or Disables whether the SoundEffectInstance should repeat after playback.
member.remarks: This value has no effect on an already playing sound.

member.summary: Gets or sets the pan, or speaker balance..
member.value: Pan value ranging from -1.0 (left speaker) to 0.0 (centered), 1.0 (right speaker). Values outside of this range will throw an exception.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Audio.SoundEffectInstance.Pitch
member.summary: Gets or sets the pitch adjustment.
member.value: Pitch adjustment, ranging from -1.0 (down an octave) to 0.0 (no change) to 1.0 (up an octave). Values outside of this range will throw an Exception.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Audio.SoundEffectInstance.Volume
member.summary: Gets or sets the volume of the SoundEffectInstance.
member.value: Volume, ranging from 0.0 (silence) to 1.0 (full volume). Volume during playback is scaled by SoundEffect.MasterVolume.
member.remarks: This is the volume relative to SoundEffect.MasterVolume. Before playback, this Volume property is multiplied by SoundEffect.MasterVolume when determining the final mix volume.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Audio.InstancePlayLimitException
member.summary: The exception thrown when the system attempts to play more SoundEffectInstances than allotted.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Audio.NoAudioHardwareException

member.name: M:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Audio.NoAudioHardwareException.#ctor(System.String,System.Exception)

member.name: T:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Audio.SoundEffect
member.summary: Represents a loaded sound resource.

remarks.para: A SoundEffect represents the buffer used to hold audio data and metadata. SoundEffectInstances are used to play from SoundEffects. Multiple SoundEffectInstance objects can be created and played from the same SoundEffect object.
The only limit on the number of loaded SoundEffects is restricted by available memory. When a SoundEffect is disposed, all SoundEffectInstances created from it will become invalid.
SoundEffect.Play() can be used for 'fire and forget' sounds. If advanced playback controls like volume or pitch is required, use SoundEffect.CreateInstance().

member.name: M:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Audio.SoundEffect.#ctor(System.Byte[],System.Int32,Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Audio.AudioChannels)
member.summary: Create a sound effect.
member.param: The buffer with the sound data.
The sound data sample rate in hertz.
The number of channels in the sound data.
member.remarks: This only supports uncompressed 16bit PCM wav data.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Audio.SoundEffect.#ctor(System.Byte[],System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Audio.AudioChannels,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Create a sound effect.
member.param: The buffer with the sound data.
The offset to the start of the sound data in bytes.
The length of the sound data in bytes.
The sound data sample rate in hertz.
The number of channels in the sound data.
The position where the sound should begin looping in samples.
The duration of the sound data loop in samples.
member.remarks: This only supports uncompressed 16bit PCM wav data.

Sample rate, in Hertz (Hz), of audio data. Must be between 8,000 and 48,000 Hz.
Number of channels in the audio data.
member.returns: The size in bytes of a single sample of audio data.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Audio.SoundEffect.Play
member.summary: Gets an internal SoundEffectInstance and plays it.
member.returns: True if a SoundEffectInstance was successfully played, false if not.

remarks.para: Play returns false if more SoundEffectInstances are currently playing then the platform allows.
To loop a sound or apply 3D effects, call SoundEffect.CreateInstance() and SoundEffectInstance.Play() instead.
SoundEffectInstances used by SoundEffect.Play() are pooled internally.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Audio.SoundEffect.Play(System.Single,System.Single,System.Single)
member.summary: Gets an internal SoundEffectInstance and plays it with the specified volume, pitch, and panning.
member.returns: True if a SoundEffectInstance was successfully created and played, false if not.
member.param: Volume, ranging from 0.0 (silence) to 1.0 (full volume). Volume during playback is scaled by SoundEffect.MasterVolume.
Pitch adjustment, ranging from -1.0 (down an octave) to 0.0 (no change) to 1.0 (up an octave).
Panning, ranging from -1.0 (left speaker) to 0.0 (centered), 1.0 (right speaker).

remarks.para: Play returns false if more SoundEffectInstances are currently playing then the platform allows.
To apply looping or simulate 3D audio, call SoundEffect.CreateInstance() and SoundEffectInstance.Play() instead.
SoundEffectInstances used by SoundEffect.Play() are pooled internally.

If the disposing parameter is false, Dispose was called by the finalizer and no managed objects should be touched because we do not know if they are still valid or not at that time. member.summary: Initializes XAudio.

member.summary: Gets the duration of the SoundEffect.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Audio.SoundEffect.Name
member.summary: Gets or sets the asset name of the SoundEffect.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Audio.SoundEffect.MasterVolume
member.summary: Gets or sets the master volume scale applied to all SoundEffectInstances.

remarks.para: Each SoundEffectInstance has its own Volume property that is independent to SoundEffect.MasterVolume. During playback SoundEffectInstance.Volume is multiplied by SoundEffect.MasterVolume.
This property is used to adjust the volume on all current and newly created SoundEffectInstances. The volume of an individual SoundEffectInstance can be adjusted on its own.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Audio.SoundEffect.DistanceScale
member.summary: Gets or sets the scale of distance calculations.

remarks.para: DistanceScale defaults to 1.0 and must be greater than 0.0.
Higher values reduce the rate of falloff between the sound and listener.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Audio.SoundEffect.DopplerScale
member.summary: Gets or sets the scale of Doppler calculations applied to sounds.

remarks.para: DopplerScale defaults to 1.0 and must be greater or equal to 0.0
Affects the relative velocity of emitters and listeners.
Higher values more dramatically shift the pitch for the given relative velocity of the emitter and listener.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Audio.SoundEffect.SpeedOfSound
member.summary: Returns the speed of sound used when calculating the Doppler effect..

remarks.para: Defaults to 343.5. Value is measured in meters per second.
Has no effect on distance attenuation.

member.summary: Sets the value of a cue-instance variable based on its friendly name.
member.param: Friendly name of the variable to set.
Value to assign to the variable.
member.remarks: The friendly name is a value set from the designer.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Audio.Cue.GetVariable(System.String)
member.summary: Gets a cue-instance variable value based on its friendly name.
member.returns: Value of the variable.

remarks.para: Cue-instance variables are useful when multiple instantiations of a single cue (and its associated sounds) are required (for example, a "car" cue where there may be more than one car at any given time). While a global variable allows multiple audio elements to be controlled in unison, a cue instance variable grants discrete control of each instance of a cue, even for each copy of the same cue.
The friendly name is a value set from the designer.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Audio.Cue.Apply3D(Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Audio.AudioListener,Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Audio.AudioEmitter)
member.summary: Updates the simulated 3D Audio settings calculated between an AudioEmitter and AudioListener.

remarks.para: This must be called before Play().

Calling this method automatically converts the sound to monoaural and sets the speaker mix for any sound played by this cue to a value calculated with the listener's and emitter's positions. Any stereo information in the sound will be discarded.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Audio.WaveBank.#ctor(Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Audio.AudioEngine,System.String,System.Int32,System.Int16)
member.param: Instance of the AudioEngine to associate this wave bank with.
Path to the .xwb to stream from.
DVD sector-aligned offset within the wave bank data file.
Stream packet size, in sectors, to use for each stream. The minimum value is 2.

remarks.para: This constructor streams wave data as needed.
Note that packetsize is in sectors, which is 2048 bytes.
AudioEngine.Update() must be called at least once before using data from a streaming wave bank.

member.summary: The default back buffer width.

member.summary: The default back buffer height.

member.summary: Associates this graphics device manager to a game instances.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.GraphicsDeviceManager.DoPreparingDeviceSettings
member.summary: This populates a GraphicsDeviceInformation instance and invokes PreparingDeviceSettings to allow users to change the settings. Then returns that GraphicsDeviceInformation. Throws NullReferenceException if users set GraphicsDeviceInformation.PresentationParameters to null.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.GraphicsDeviceManager.ApplyChanges
member.summary: Applies any pending property changes to the graphics device.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.GraphicsDeviceManager.ToggleFullScreen
member.summary: Toggles between windowed and fullscreen modes.
member.remarks: Note that on platforms that do not support windowed modes this has no affect.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.GraphicsDeviceManager.GraphicsProfile
member.summary: The profile which determines the graphics feature level.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.GraphicsDeviceManager.GraphicsDevice
member.summary: Returns the graphics device for this manager.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.GraphicsDeviceManager.IsFullScreen
member.summary: Indicates the desire to switch into fullscreen mode.
member.remarks: When called at startup this will automatically set fullscreen mode during initialization. If set after startup you must call ApplyChanges() for the fullscreen mode to be changed. Note that for some platforms that do not support windowed modes this property has no affect.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.GraphicsDeviceManager.HardwareModeSwitch
member.summary: Gets or sets the boolean which defines how window switches from windowed to fullscreen state. "Hard" mode(true) is slow to switch, but more effecient for performance, while "soft" mode(false) is vice versa. The default value is true.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.GraphicsDeviceManager.PreferMultiSampling
member.summary: Indicates the desire for a multisampled back buffer.
member.remarks: When called at startup this will automatically set the MSAA mode during initialization. If set after startup you must call ApplyChanges() for the MSAA mode to be changed.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.GraphicsDeviceManager.PreferredBackBufferFormat
member.summary: Indicates the desired back buffer color format.
member.remarks: When called at startup this will automatically set the format during initialization. If set after startup you must call ApplyChanges() for the format to be changed.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.GraphicsDeviceManager.PreferredBackBufferHeight
member.summary: Indicates the desired back buffer height in pixels.
member.remarks: When called at startup this will automatically set the height during initialization. If set after startup you must call ApplyChanges() for the height to be changed.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.GraphicsDeviceManager.PreferredBackBufferWidth
member.summary: Indicates the desired back buffer width in pixels.
member.remarks: When called at startup this will automatically set the width during initialization. If set after startup you must call ApplyChanges() for the width to be changed.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.GraphicsDeviceManager.PreferredDepthStencilFormat
member.summary: Indicates the desired depth-stencil buffer format.
member.remarks: The depth-stencil buffer format defines the scene depth precision and stencil bits available for effects during rendering. When called at startup this will automatically set the format during initialization. If set after startup you must call ApplyChanges() for the format to be changed.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.GraphicsDeviceManager.SynchronizeWithVerticalRetrace
member.summary: Indicates the desire for vsync when presenting the back buffer.
member.remarks: Vsync limits the frame rate of the game to the monitor referesh rate to prevent screen tearing. When called at startup this will automatically set the vsync mode during initialization. If set after startup you must call ApplyChanges() for the vsync mode to be changed.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.GraphicsDeviceManager.SupportedOrientations
member.summary: Indicates the desired allowable display orientations when the device is rotated.
member.remarks: This property only applies to mobile platforms with automatic display rotation. When called at startup this will automatically apply the supported orientations during initialization. If set after startup you must call ApplyChanges() for the supported orientations to be changed.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.EnvironmentMapEffect.EnvironmentMapAmount
member.summary: Gets or sets the amount of the environment map RGB that will be blended over the base texture. Range 0 to 1, default 1. If set to zero, the RGB channels of the environment map will completely ignored (but the environment map alpha may still be visible if EnvironmentMapSpecular is greater than zero).

member.name: P:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.EnvironmentMapEffect.EnvironmentMapSpecular
member.summary: Gets or sets the amount of the environment map alpha channel that will be added to the base texture. Range 0 to 1, default 0. This can be used to implement cheap specular lighting, by encoding one or more specular highlight patterns into the environment map alpha channel, then setting EnvironmentMapSpecular to the desired specular light color.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.EnvironmentMapEffect.FresnelFactor
member.summary: Gets or sets the Fresnel factor used for the environment map blending. Higher values make the environment map only visible around the silhouette edges of the object, while lower values make it visible everywhere. Setting this property to 0 disables Fresnel entirely, making the environment map equally visible regardless of view angle. The default is 1. Fresnel only affects the environment map RGB (the intensity of which is controlled by EnvironmentMapAmount). The alpha contribution (controlled by EnvironmentMapSpecular) is not affected by the Fresnel setting.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.PresentInterval
member.summary: Defines how updates the game window.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.PresentInterval.Default
member.summary: Equivalent to .

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.PresentInterval.One
member.summary: The driver waits for the vertical retrace period, before updating window client area. Present operations are not affected more frequently than the screen refresh rate.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.PresentInterval.Two
member.summary: The driver waits for the vertical retrace period, before updating window client area. Present operations are not affected more frequently than every second screen refresh.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.PresentInterval.Immediate
member.summary: The driver updates the window client area immediately. Present operations might be affected immediately. There is no limit for framerate.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.VertexBuffer.SetData``1(System.Int32,``0[],System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Sets the vertex buffer data, specifying the index at which to start copying from the source data array, the number of elements to copy from the source data array, and how far apart elements from the source data array should be when they are copied into the vertex buffer.
member.typeparam: Type of elements in the data array.
member.param: Offset in bytes from the beginning of the vertex buffer to the start of the copied data.
Index at which to start copying from . Must be within the array bounds.
Number of elements to copy from . The combination of and must be within the array bounds.

Specifies how far apart, in bytes, elements from should be when they are copied into the vertex buffer. In almost all cases this should be sizeof(T), to create a tightly-packed vertex buffer. If you specify sizeof(T), elements from will be copied into the vertex buffer with no padding between each element. If you specify a value greater than sizeof(T), elements from will be copied into the vertex buffer with padding between each element. If you specify 0 for this parameter, it will be treated as if you had specified sizeof(T). With the exception of 0, you must specify a value greater than or equal to sizeof(T).
member.remarks: If you provide a byte[] in the parameter, then you should almost certainly set to 1, to avoid leaving any padding between the byte values when they are copied into the vertex buffer.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.VertexBuffer.SetData``1(``0[],System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Sets the vertex buffer data, specifying the index at which to start copying from the source data array, and the number of elements to copy from the source data array. This is the same as calling with offsetInBytes equal to 0, and vertexStride equal to sizeof(T).
member.typeparam: Type of elements in the data array.
member.param: Index at which to start copying from . Must be within the array bounds.
Number of elements to copy from . The combination of and must be within the array bounds.

member.summary: Enumuration of values that represent different gestures that can be processed by .

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Input.Touch.GestureType.None
member.summary: No gestures.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Input.Touch.GestureType.Tap
member.summary: The user touched a single point.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Input.Touch.GestureType.DragComplete
member.summary: States completion of a drag gesture(VerticalDrag, HorizontalDrag, or FreeDrag).
member.remarks: No position or delta information is available for this sample.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Input.Touch.GestureType.Flick
member.summary: States that a touch was combined with a quick swipe.
member.remarks: Flicks does not contain position information. The velocity of it can be read from

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Input.Touch.GestureType.FreeDrag
member.summary: The use touched a point and then performed a free-form drag.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Input.Touch.GestureType.Hold
member.summary: The use touched a single point for approximately one second.
member.remarks: As this is a single event, it will not be contionusly fired while the user is holding the touch-point.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Input.Touch.GestureType.HorizontalDrag
member.summary: The user touched the screen and performed either left to right or right to left drag gesture.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Input.Touch.GestureType.Pinch
member.summary: The user either converged or diverged two touch-points on the screen which is like a two-finger drag.
member.remarks: When this gesture-type is enabled and two fingers are down, it takes precedence over drag gestures.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Input.Touch.GestureType.PinchComplete
member.summary: An in-progress pinch operation was completed.
member.remarks: No position or delta information is available for this sample.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Input.Touch.GestureType.DoubleTap
member.summary: The user tapped the device twice which is always preceded by a Tap gesture.
member.remarks: If the time between two touchs are long enough, insted two seperate single Tap gestures will be generated.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Input.Touch.GestureType.VerticalDrag
member.summary: The user touched the screen and performed either top to bottom or bottom to top drag gesture.

member.name: T:MonoGame.Utilities.ZlibStream
member.summary: Represents a Zlib stream for compression or decompression.

remarks.para: The ZlibStream is a Decorator on a . It adds ZLIB compression or decompression to any stream.

Using this stream, applications can compress or decompress data via stream Read() and Write() operations. Either compression or decompression can occur through either reading or writing. The compression format used is ZLIB, which is documented in IETF RFC 1950, "ZLIB Compressed Data Format Specification version 3.3". This implementation of ZLIB always uses DEFLATE as the compression method. (see IETF RFC 1951, "DEFLATE Compressed Data Format Specification version 1.3.")

The ZLIB format allows for varying compression methods, window sizes, and dictionaries. This implementation always uses the DEFLATE compression method, a preset dictionary, and 15 window bits by default.

This class is similar to DeflateStream, except that it adds the RFC1950 header and trailer bytes to a compressed stream when compressing, or expects the RFC1950 header and trailer bytes when decompressing. It is also similar to the .

member.name: M:MonoGame.Utilities.ZlibStream.#ctor(System.IO.Stream,MonoGame.Utilities.CompressionMode)
member.summary: Create a ZlibStream using the specified CompressionMode.

remarks.para: When mode is CompressionMode.Compress, the ZlibStream will use the default compression level. The "captive" stream will be closed when the ZlibStream is closed.

member.param: The stream which will be read or written.
Indicates whether the ZlibStream will compress or decompress.

member.name: M:MonoGame.Utilities.ZlibStream.#ctor(System.IO.Stream,MonoGame.Utilities.CompressionMode,MonoGame.Utilities.CompressionLevel)
member.summary: Create a ZlibStream using the specified CompressionMode and the specified CompressionLevel.

remarks.para: When mode is CompressionMode.Decompress, the level parameter is ignored. The "captive" stream will be closed when the ZlibStream is closed.

member.param: The stream to be read or written while deflating or inflating.
Indicates whether the ZlibStream will compress or decompress.
A tuning knob to trade speed for effectiveness.

member.name: M:MonoGame.Utilities.ZlibStream.#ctor(System.IO.Stream,MonoGame.Utilities.CompressionMode,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Create a ZlibStream using the specified CompressionMode, and explicitly specify whether the captive stream should be left open after Deflation or Inflation.

remarks.para: When mode is CompressionMode.Compress, the ZlibStream will use the default compression level.

This constructor allows the application to request that the captive stream remain open after the deflation or inflation occurs. By default, after Close() is called on the stream, the captive stream is also closed. In some cases this is not desired, for example if the stream is a that will be re-read after compression. Specify true for the parameter to leave the stream open.
See the other overloads of this constructor for example code.

member.param: The stream which will be read or written. This is called the "captive" stream in other places in this documentation.
Indicates whether the ZlibStream will compress or decompress.
true if the application would like the stream to remain open after inflation/deflation.

member.name: M:MonoGame.Utilities.ZlibStream.#ctor(System.IO.Stream,MonoGame.Utilities.CompressionMode,MonoGame.Utilities.CompressionLevel,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Create a ZlibStream using the specified CompressionMode and the specified CompressionLevel, and explicitly specify whether the stream should be left open after Deflation or Inflation.

remarks.para: This constructor allows the application to request that the captive stream remain open after the deflation or inflation occurs. By default, after Close() is called on the stream, the captive stream is also closed. In some cases this is not desired, for example if the stream is a that will be re-read after compression. Specify true for the parameter to leave the stream open.
When mode is CompressionMode.Decompress, the level parameter is ignored.

member.param: The stream which will be read or written.
Indicates whether the ZlibStream will compress or decompress.
true if the application would like the stream to remain open after inflation/deflation.
A tuning knob to trade speed for effectiveness. This parameter is effective only when mode is CompressionMode.Compress.

member.name: M:MonoGame.Utilities.ZlibStream.Dispose(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Dispose the stream.

remarks.para: This may or may not result in a Close() call on the captive stream. See the constructors that have a leaveOpen parameter for more information.

This method may be invoked in two distinct scenarios. If disposing == true, the method has been called directly or indirectly by a user's code, for example via the public Dispose() method. In this case, both managed and unmanaged resources can be referenced and disposed. If disposing == false, the method has been called by the runtime from inside the object finalizer and this method should not reference other objects; in that case only unmanaged resources must be referenced or disposed.

member.param: indicates whether the Dispose method was invoked by user code.

member.name: M:MonoGame.Utilities.ZlibStream.Flush
member.summary: Flush the stream.

member.name: M:MonoGame.Utilities.ZlibStream.Read(System.Byte[],System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Read data from the stream.

remarks.para: If you wish to use the ZlibStream to compress data while reading, you can create a ZlibStream with CompressionMode.Compress, providing an uncompressed data stream. Then call Read() on that ZlibStream, and the data read will be compressed. If you wish to use the ZlibStream to decompress data while reading, you can create a ZlibStream with CompressionMode.Decompress, providing a readable compressed data stream. Then call Read() on that ZlibStream, and the data will be decompressed as it is read.
A ZlibStream can be used for Read() or Write(), but not both.

member.param: The buffer into which the read data should be placed.
the offset within that data array to put the first byte read.
the number of bytes to read.
member.returns: the number of bytes read

member.name: M:MonoGame.Utilities.ZlibStream.Seek(System.Int64,System.IO.SeekOrigin)
member.summary: Calling this method always throws a .
member.param: The offset to seek to.... IF THIS METHOD ACTUALLY DID ANYTHING.
The reference specifying how to apply the offset.... IF THIS METHOD ACTUALLY DID ANYTHING.
member.returns: nothing. This method always throws.

member.name: M:MonoGame.Utilities.ZlibStream.SetLength(System.Int64)
member.summary: Calling this method always throws a .
member.param: The new value for the stream length.... IF THIS METHOD ACTUALLY DID ANYTHING.

member.name: M:MonoGame.Utilities.ZlibStream.Write(System.Byte[],System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Write data to the stream.

remarks.para: If you wish to use the ZlibStream to compress data while writing, you can create a ZlibStream with CompressionMode.Compress, and a writable output stream. Then call Write() on that ZlibStream, providing uncompressed data as input. The data sent to the output stream will be the compressed form of the data written. If you wish to use the ZlibStream to decompress data while writing, you can create a ZlibStream with CompressionMode.Decompress, and a writable output stream. Then call Write() on that stream, providing previously compressed data. The data sent to the output stream will be the decompressed form of the data written.
A ZlibStream can be used for Read() or Write(), but not both.

member.param: The buffer holding data to write to the stream.
the offset within that data array to find the first byte to write.
the number of bytes to write.

member.name: P:MonoGame.Utilities.ZlibStream.BufferSize
member.summary: The size of the working buffer for the compression codec.

remarks.para: The working buffer is used for all stream operations. The default size is 1024 bytes. The minimum size is 128 bytes. You may get better performance with a larger buffer. Then again, you might not. You would have to test it.
Set this before the first call to Read() or Write() on the stream. If you try to set it afterwards, it will throw.

member.name: T:MonoGame.Utilities.ZlibCodec
member.summary: Encoder and Decoder for ZLIB and DEFLATE (IETF RFC1950 and RFC1951).
member.remarks: This class compresses and decompresses data according to the Deflate algorithm and optionally, the ZLIB format, as documented in RFC 1950 - ZLIB and RFC 1951 - DEFLATE.

member.name: F:MonoGame.Utilities.ZlibCodec.InputBuffer
member.summary: The buffer from which data is taken.

member.name: F:MonoGame.Utilities.ZlibCodec.NextIn
member.summary: An index into the InputBuffer array, indicating where to start reading.

member.name: F:MonoGame.Utilities.ZlibCodec.AvailableBytesIn
member.summary: The number of bytes available in the InputBuffer, starting at NextIn.
member.remarks: Generally you should set this to InputBuffer.Length before the first Inflate() or Deflate() call. The class will update this number as calls to Inflate/Deflate are made.

member.name: F:MonoGame.Utilities.ZlibCodec.TotalBytesIn
member.summary: Total number of bytes read so far, through all calls to Inflate()/Deflate().

member.name: F:MonoGame.Utilities.ZlibCodec.OutputBuffer
member.summary: Buffer to store output data.

member.name: F:MonoGame.Utilities.ZlibCodec.NextOut
member.summary: An index into the OutputBuffer array, indicating where to start writing.

member.name: F:MonoGame.Utilities.ZlibCodec.AvailableBytesOut
member.summary: The number of bytes available in the OutputBuffer, starting at NextOut.
member.remarks: Generally you should set this to OutputBuffer.Length before the first Inflate() or Deflate() call. The class will update this number as calls to Inflate/Deflate are made.

member.name: F:MonoGame.Utilities.ZlibCodec.TotalBytesOut
member.summary: Total number of bytes written to the output so far, through all calls to Inflate()/Deflate().

member.name: F:MonoGame.Utilities.ZlibCodec.Message
member.summary: used for diagnostics, when something goes wrong!

member.name: F:MonoGame.Utilities.ZlibCodec.CompressLevel
member.summary: The compression level to use in this codec. Useful only in compression mode.

member.name: F:MonoGame.Utilities.ZlibCodec.WindowBits
member.summary: The number of Window Bits to use.
member.remarks: This gauges the size of the sliding window, and hence the compression effectiveness as well as memory consumption. It's best to just leave this setting alone if you don't know what it is. The maximum value is 15 bits, which implies a 32k window.

member.name: F:MonoGame.Utilities.ZlibCodec.Strategy
member.summary: The compression strategy to use.
member.remarks: This is only effective in compression. The theory offered by ZLIB is that different strategies could potentially produce significant differences in compression behavior for different data sets. Unfortunately I don't have any good recommendations for how to set it differently. When I tested changing the strategy I got minimally different compression performance. It's best to leave this property alone if you don't have a good feel for it. Or, you may want to produce a test harness that runs through the different strategy options and evaluates them on different file types. If you do that, let me know your results.

member.name: M:MonoGame.Utilities.ZlibCodec.#ctor
member.summary: Create a ZlibCodec.
member.remarks: If you use this default constructor, you will later have to explicitly call InitializeInflate() or InitializeDeflate() before using the ZlibCodec to compress or decompress.

member.summary: Create a ZlibCodec that either compresses or decompresses.

member.name: M:MonoGame.Utilities.ZlibCodec.InitializeInflate
member.summary: Initialize the inflation state.
member.remarks: It is not necessary to call this before using the ZlibCodec to inflate data; It is implicitly called when you call the constructor.
member.returns: Z_OK if everything goes well.

member.name: M:MonoGame.Utilities.ZlibCodec.InitializeInflate(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Initialize the inflation state with an explicit flag to govern the handling of RFC1950 header bytes.
member.remarks: By default, the ZLIB header defined in RFC 1950 is expected. If you want to read a zlib stream you should specify true for expectRfc1950Header. If you have a deflate stream, you will want to specify false. It is only necessary to invoke this initializer explicitly if you want to specify false.
member.param: whether to expect an RFC1950 header byte pair when reading the stream of data to be inflated.
member.returns: Z_OK if everything goes well.

member.name: M:MonoGame.Utilities.ZlibCodec.InitializeInflate(System.Int32)
member.summary: Initialize the ZlibCodec for inflation, with the specified number of window bits.
member.param: The number of window bits to use. If you need to ask what that is, then you shouldn't be calling this initializer.
member.returns: Z_OK if all goes well.

member.name: M:MonoGame.Utilities.ZlibCodec.InitializeInflate(System.Int32,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Initialize the inflation state with an explicit flag to govern the handling of RFC1950 header bytes.
member.remarks: If you want to read a zlib stream you should specify true for expectRfc1950Header. In this case, the library will expect to find a ZLIB header, as defined in RFC 1950, in the compressed stream. If you will be reading a DEFLATE or GZIP stream, which does not have such a header, you will want to specify false.
member.param: whether to expect an RFC1950 header byte pair when reading the stream of data to be inflated.
The number of window bits to use. If you need to ask what that is, then you shouldn't be calling this initializer.
member.returns: Z_OK if everything goes well.

member.name: M:MonoGame.Utilities.ZlibCodec.Inflate(MonoGame.Utilities.FlushType)
member.summary: Inflate the data in the InputBuffer, placing the result in the OutputBuffer.
member.remarks: You must have set InputBuffer and OutputBuffer, NextIn and NextOut, and AvailableBytesIn and AvailableBytesOut before calling this method.
member.param: The flush to use when inflating.
member.returns: Z_OK if everything goes well.

member.name: M:MonoGame.Utilities.ZlibCodec.EndInflate
member.summary: Ends an inflation session.
member.remarks: Call this after successively calling Inflate(). This will cause all buffers to be flushed. After calling this you cannot call Inflate() without a intervening call to one of the InitializeInflate() overloads.
member.returns: Z_OK if everything goes well.

member.name: M:MonoGame.Utilities.ZlibCodec.SyncInflate
member.summary: I don't know what this does!
member.returns: Z_OK if everything goes well.

member.name: M:MonoGame.Utilities.ZlibCodec.InitializeDeflate
member.summary: Initialize the ZlibCodec for deflation operation.
member.remarks: The codec will use the MAX window bits and the default level of compression.
member.returns: Z_OK if all goes well. You generally don't need to check the return code.

member.summary: Initialize the ZlibCodec for deflation operation, using the specified CompressionLevel.
member.remarks: The codec will use the maximum window bits (15) and the specified CompressionLevel. It will emit a ZLIB stream as it compresses.
member.param: The compression level for the codec.
member.returns: Z_OK if all goes well.

member.remarks: The codec will use the maximum window bits (15) and the specified CompressionLevel. If you want to generate a zlib stream, you should specify true for wantRfc1950Header. In this case, the library will emit a ZLIB header, as defined in RFC 1950, in the compressed stream.
member.param: The compression level for the codec.
whether to emit an initial RFC1950 byte pair in the compressed stream.
member.returns: Z_OK if all goes well.

the number of window bits to use. If you don't know what this means, don't use this method.
member.returns: Z_OK if all goes well.

whether to emit an initial RFC1950 byte pair in the compressed stream.
the number of window bits to use. If you don't know what this means, don't use this method.

member.name: M:MonoGame.Utilities.ZlibCodec.Deflate(MonoGame.Utilities.FlushType)
member.summary: Deflate one batch of data.
member.remarks: You must have set InputBuffer and OutputBuffer before calling this method.
member.param: whether to flush all data as you deflate. Generally you will want to use Z_NO_FLUSH here, in a series of calls to Deflate(), and then call EndDeflate() to flush everything.

member.summary: End a deflation session.
member.remarks: Call this after making a series of one or more calls to Deflate(). All buffers are flushed.
member.returns: Z_OK if all goes well.

member.name: M:MonoGame.Utilities.ZlibCodec.ResetDeflate
member.summary: Reset a codec for another deflation session.
member.remarks: Call this to reset the deflation state. For example if a thread is deflating non-consecutive blocks, you can call Reset() after the Deflate(Sync) of the first block and before the next Deflate(None) of the second block.
member.returns: Z_OK if all goes well.

member.name: M:MonoGame.Utilities.ZlibCodec.SetDeflateParams(MonoGame.Utilities.CompressionLevel,MonoGame.Utilities.CompressionStrategy)
member.summary: Set the CompressionStrategy and CompressionLevel for a deflation session.
member.param: the level of compression to use.
the strategy to use for compression.
member.returns: Z_OK if all goes well.

member.name: M:MonoGame.Utilities.ZlibCodec.SetDictionary(System.Byte[])
member.summary: Set the dictionary to be used for either Inflation or Deflation.
member.returns: Z_OK if all goes well.

member.name: P:MonoGame.Utilities.ZlibCodec.Adler32
member.summary: The Adler32 checksum on the data transferred through the codec so far. You probably don't need to look at this.

member.name: T:MonoGame.Utilities.FlushType
member.summary: Describes how to flush the current deflate operation.
member.remarks: The different FlushType values are useful when using a Deflate in a streaming application.

member.name: F:MonoGame.Utilities.FlushType.None
member.summary: No flush at all.

member.name: F:MonoGame.Utilities.FlushType.Partial
member.summary: Closes the current block, but doesn't flush it to the output. Used internally only in hypothetical scenarios. This was supposed to be removed by Zlib, but it is still in use in some edge cases.

member.name: F:MonoGame.Utilities.FlushType.Sync
member.summary: Use this during compression to specify that all pending output should be flushed to the output buffer and the output should be aligned on a byte boundary. You might use this in a streaming communication scenario, so that the decompressor can get all input data available so far. When using this with a ZlibCodec, AvailableBytesIn will be zero after the call if enough output space has been provided before the call. Flushing will degrade compression and so it should be used only when necessary.

member.name: F:MonoGame.Utilities.FlushType.Full
member.summary: Use this during compression to specify that all output should be flushed, as with FlushType.Sync, but also, the compression state should be reset so that decompression can restart from this point if previous compressed data has been damaged or if random access is desired. Using FlushType.Full too often can significantly degrade the compression.

member.name: F:MonoGame.Utilities.FlushType.Finish
member.summary: Signals the end of the compression/decompression stream.

member.name: T:MonoGame.Utilities.CompressionLevel
member.summary: The compression level to be used when using a DeflateStream or ZlibStream with CompressionMode.Compress.

member.name: F:MonoGame.Utilities.CompressionLevel.None
member.summary: None means that the data will be simply stored, with no change at all. If you are producing ZIPs for use on Mac OSX, be aware that archives produced with CompressionLevel.None cannot be opened with the default zip reader. Use a different CompressionLevel.

member.name: F:MonoGame.Utilities.CompressionLevel.Level0
member.summary: Same as None.

member.name: F:MonoGame.Utilities.CompressionLevel.BestSpeed
member.summary: The fastest but least effective compression.

member.name: F:MonoGame.Utilities.CompressionLevel.Level1
member.summary: A synonym for BestSpeed.

member.name: F:MonoGame.Utilities.CompressionLevel.Level2
member.summary: A little slower, but better, than level 1.

member.name: F:MonoGame.Utilities.CompressionLevel.Level3
member.summary: A little slower, but better, than level 2.

member.name: F:MonoGame.Utilities.CompressionLevel.Level4
member.summary: A little slower, but better, than level 3.

member.name: F:MonoGame.Utilities.CompressionLevel.Level5
member.summary: A little slower than level 4, but with better compression.

member.name: F:MonoGame.Utilities.CompressionLevel.Default
member.summary: The default compression level, with a good balance of speed and compression efficiency.

member.name: F:MonoGame.Utilities.CompressionLevel.Level6
member.summary: A synonym for Default.

member.name: F:MonoGame.Utilities.CompressionLevel.Level7
member.summary: Pretty good compression!

member.name: F:MonoGame.Utilities.CompressionLevel.Level8
member.summary: Better compression than Level7!

member.name: F:MonoGame.Utilities.CompressionLevel.BestCompression
member.summary: The "best" compression, where best means greatest reduction in size of the input data stream. This is also the slowest compression.

member.name: F:MonoGame.Utilities.CompressionLevel.Level9
member.summary: A synonym for BestCompression.

member.name: T:MonoGame.Utilities.CompressionStrategy
member.summary: Describes options for how the compression algorithm is executed. Different strategies work better on different sorts of data. The strategy parameter can affect the compression ratio and the speed of compression but not the correctness of the compresssion.

member.name: F:MonoGame.Utilities.CompressionStrategy.Default
member.summary: The default strategy is probably the best for normal data.

member.name: F:MonoGame.Utilities.CompressionStrategy.Filtered
member.summary: The Filtered strategy is intended to be used most effectively with data produced by a filter or predictor. By this definition, filtered data consists mostly of small values with a somewhat random distribution. In this case, the compression algorithm is tuned to compress them better. The effect of Filtered is to force more Huffman coding and less string matching; it is a half-step between Default and HuffmanOnly.

member.name: F:MonoGame.Utilities.CompressionStrategy.HuffmanOnly
member.summary: Using HuffmanOnly will force the compressor to do Huffman encoding only, with no string matching.

member.name: T:MonoGame.Utilities.GZipStream
member.summary: A class for compressing and decompressing GZIP streams.

remarks.para: The GZipStream is a Decorator on a . It adds GZIP compression or decompression to any stream.

Like the System.IO.Compression.GZipStream in the .NET Base Class Library, the Ionic.Zlib.GZipStream can compress while writing, or decompress while reading, but not vice versa. The compression method used is GZIP, which is documented in IETF RFC 1952, "GZIP file format specification version 4.3".
A GZipStream can be used to decompress data (through Read()) or to compress data (through Write()), but not both.

If you wish to use the GZipStream to compress data, you must wrap it around a write-able stream. As you call Write() on the GZipStream, the data will be compressed into the GZIP format. If you want to decompress data, you must wrap the GZipStream around a readable stream that contains an IETF RFC 1952-compliant stream. The data will be decompressed as you call Read() on the GZipStream.
Though the GZIP format allows data from multiple files to be concatenated together, this stream handles only a single segment of GZIP format, typically representing a single file.

member.name: F:MonoGame.Utilities.GZipStream.LastModified
member.summary: The last modified time for the GZIP stream.
member.remarks: GZIP allows the storage of a last modified time with each GZIP entry. When compressing data, you can set this before the first call to Write(). When decompressing, you can retrieve this value any time after the first call to Read().

member.name: M:MonoGame.Utilities.GZipStream.#ctor(System.IO.Stream,MonoGame.Utilities.CompressionMode)
member.summary: Create a GZipStream using the specified CompressionMode.

remarks.para: When mode is CompressionMode.Compress, the GZipStream will use the default compression level.

As noted in the class documentation, the CompressionMode (Compress or Decompress) also establishes the "direction" of the stream. A GZipStream with CompressionMode.Compress works only through Write(). A GZipStream with CompressionMode.Decompress works only through Read().

member.param: The stream which will be read or written.
Indicates whether the GZipStream will compress or decompress.

member.name: M:MonoGame.Utilities.GZipStream.#ctor(System.IO.Stream,MonoGame.Utilities.CompressionMode,MonoGame.Utilities.CompressionLevel)
member.summary: Create a GZipStream using the specified CompressionMode and the specified CompressionLevel.

remarks.para: The CompressionMode (Compress or Decompress) also establishes the "direction" of the stream. A GZipStream with CompressionMode.Compress works only through Write(). A GZipStream with CompressionMode.Decompress works only through Read().

member.param: The stream to be read or written while deflating or inflating.
Indicates whether the GZipStream will compress or decompress.
A tuning knob to trade speed for effectiveness.

member.name: M:MonoGame.Utilities.GZipStream.#ctor(System.IO.Stream,MonoGame.Utilities.CompressionMode,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Create a GZipStream using the specified CompressionMode, and explicitly specify whether the stream should be left open after Deflation or Inflation.

remarks.para: This constructor allows the application to request that the captive stream remain open after the deflation or inflation occurs. By default, after Close() is called on the stream, the captive stream is also closed. In some cases this is not desired, for example if the stream is a memory stream that will be re-read after compressed data has been written to it. Specify true for the parameter to leave the stream open.

The (Compress or Decompress) also establishes the "direction" of the stream. A GZipStream with CompressionMode.Compress works only through Write(). A GZipStream with CompressionMode.Decompress works only through Read().
The GZipStream will use the default compression level. If you want to specify the compression level, see .
See the other overloads of this constructor for example code.

member.param: The stream which will be read or written. This is called the "captive" stream in other places in this documentation.
Indicates whether the GZipStream will compress or decompress.
true if the application would like the base stream to remain open after inflation/deflation.

member.name: M:MonoGame.Utilities.GZipStream.#ctor(System.IO.Stream,MonoGame.Utilities.CompressionMode,MonoGame.Utilities.CompressionLevel,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Create a GZipStream using the specified CompressionMode and the specified CompressionLevel, and explicitly specify whether the stream should be left open after Deflation or Inflation.

remarks.para: This constructor allows the application to request that the captive stream remain open after the deflation or inflation occurs. By default, after Close() is called on the stream, the captive stream is also closed. In some cases this is not desired, for example if the stream is a memory stream that will be re-read after compressed data has been written to it. Specify true for the parameter to leave the stream open.

As noted in the class documentation, the CompressionMode (Compress or Decompress) also establishes the "direction" of the stream. A GZipStream with CompressionMode.Compress works only through Write(). A GZipStream with CompressionMode.Decompress works only through Read().

member.param: The stream which will be read or written.
Indicates whether the GZipStream will compress or decompress.
true if the application would like the stream to remain open after inflation/deflation.
A tuning knob to trade speed for effectiveness.

member.name: M:MonoGame.Utilities.GZipStream.Dispose(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Dispose the stream.

remarks.para: This may or may not result in a Close() call on the captive stream. See the constructors that have a leaveOpen parameter for more information.

This method may be invoked in two distinct scenarios. If disposing == true, the method has been called directly or indirectly by a user's code, for example via the internal Dispose() method. In this case, both managed and unmanaged resources can be referenced and disposed. If disposing == false, the method has been called by the runtime from inside the object finalizer and this method should not reference other objects; in that case only unmanaged resources must be referenced or disposed.

member.param: indicates whether the Dispose method was invoked by user code.

member.summary: Write data to the stream.

remarks.para: If you wish to use the GZipStream to compress data while writing, you can create a GZipStream with CompressionMode.Compress, and a writable output stream. Then call Write() on that GZipStream, providing uncompressed data as input. The data sent to the output stream will be the compressed form of the data written.
A GZipStream can be used for Read() or Write(), but not both. Writing implies compression. Reading implies decompression.

member.param: The buffer holding data to write to the stream.
the offset within that data array to find the first byte to write.
the number of bytes to write.

member.name: P:MonoGame.Utilities.GZipStream.Comment
member.summary: The comment on the GZIP stream.

remarks.para: The GZIP format allows for each file to optionally have an associated comment stored with the file. The comment is encoded with the ISO-8859-1 code page. To include a comment in a GZIP stream you create, set this property before calling Write() for the first time on the GZipStream.

When using GZipStream to decompress, you can retrieve this property after the first call to Read(). If no comment has been set in the GZIP bytestream, the Comment property will return null (Nothing in VB).

member.name: P:MonoGame.Utilities.GZipStream.FileName
member.summary: The FileName for the GZIP stream.

remarks.para: The GZIP format optionally allows each file to have an associated filename. When compressing data (through Write()), set this FileName before calling Write() the first time on the GZipStream. The actual filename is encoded into the GZIP bytestream with the ISO-8859-1 code page, according to RFC 1952. It is the application's responsibility to insure that the FileName can be encoded and decoded correctly with this code page.

When decompressing (through Read()), you can retrieve this value any time after the first Read(). In the case where there was no filename encoded into the GZIP bytestream, the property will return null (Nothing in VB).

member.name: P:MonoGame.Utilities.GZipStream.BufferSize
member.summary: The size of the working buffer for the compression codec.

remarks.para: The working buffer is used for all stream operations. The default size is 1024 bytes. The minimum size is 128 bytes. You may get better performance with a larger buffer. Then again, you might not. You would have to test it.
Set this before the first call to Read() or Write() on the stream. If you try to set it afterwards, it will throw.

member.name: M:MonoGame.Utilities.CRC32.#ctor
member.summary: Create an instance of the CRC32 class using the default settings: no bit reversal, and a polynomial of 0xEDB88320.

member.name: M:MonoGame.Utilities.CRC32.#ctor(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Create an instance of the CRC32 class, specifying whether to reverse data bits or not.
member.param: specify true if the instance should reverse data bits.

remarks.para: In the CRC-32 used by BZip2, the bits are reversed. Therefore if you want a CRC32 with compatibility with BZip2, you should pass true here. In the CRC-32 used by GZIP and PKZIP, the bits are not reversed; Therefore if you want a CRC32 with compatibility with those, you should pass false.

member.name: M:MonoGame.Utilities.CRC32.#ctor(System.Int32,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Create an instance of the CRC32 class, specifying the polynomial and whether to reverse data bits or not.
member.param: The polynomial to use for the CRC, expressed in the reversed (LSB) format: the highest ordered bit in the polynomial value is the coefficient of the 0th power; the second-highest order bit is the coefficient of the 1 power, and so on. Expressed this way, the polynomial for the CRC-32C used in IEEE 802.3, is 0xEDB88320.
specify true if the instance should reverse data bits.

remarks.para: In the CRC-32 used by BZip2, the bits are reversed. Therefore if you want a CRC32 with compatibility with BZip2, you should pass true here for the reverseBits parameter. In the CRC-32 used by GZIP and PKZIP, the bits are not reversed; Therefore if you want a CRC32 with compatibility with those, you should pass false for the reverseBits parameter.

member.summary: Gets the number of characters that are supported by this encoding. This property returns a maximum value of 256, as the encoding class only supports single byte encodings (1 byte == 256 possible values).

member.name: M:MonoGame.Utilities.Png.PngWriter.GetOptimalFilteredScanline(System.Byte[],System.Byte[],System.Int32)
member.summary: Applies all PNG filters to the given scanline and returns the filtered scanline that is deemed to be most compressible, using lowest total variation as proxy for compressibility.

member.name: M:MonoGame.Utilities.Png.PngWriter.CalculateTotalVariation(System.Byte[])
member.summary: Calculates the total variation of given byte array. Total variation is the sum of the absolute values of neighbour differences.
